content.description: Start on the good, flat edges, and muster some creativity with multiple options overhead for your left hand and the crack feature for your right hand. Climb to the top from there.
content.protection: 2 pads to protect the rocky landing zone.
content.location: It is in the lower set of lower boulders near the mountain bike trail and ascends the short, overhung, lil' guy.

content.description: Stand start on two right-facing sidepulls/ribs, and follow the runnel to the top on good holds.
content.location: It ascends the first boulder in the Lowers on obvious runnel features.

content.description: Sit start with your right hand in the namesake pocket and your left hand on a sloping lip. Pull up and left to a decent edge, and follow crimps to the top. This has cool features.
content.location: It is downhill to the final group of boulders in the Lowers and right next to the mountain bike trail on the east face. The trail leads you straight into it.

content.description:
Climb directly up the middle face of the boulder from a sit start. This is probably the most obvious line on the whole thing, but it is significantly harder than any other problem here. From the low guano rail, pull hard up to a sloping edge with your right hand, do some foot magic, then work left into the sidepulls and onto a flake higher up the face. The angle starts around 20 degrees overhung, but the topout is a slab. This thing could use some dedicated cleaning to really suss out, but the opening moves are good and hard.

V9 is a rough educated guess based on those first handful of moves. Wait for it to be cold for this one.
content.location: It is in the Lower 7-mile Boulders on the back side (west face) of the biggest boulder in the area - it is obvious.

content.description: Start to the right of the corner/roof climb below the road. Begin on two small edges. The hardest part is pulling onto the face.
content.location: It is on the lowest boulders below the road.

content.description: Broken Edges has fun climbing on good holds the entire way up with good height (unique for the lower area). There are probably lots of options for what to hold on to, and they're all going to be dirty, so just stick with the first one you go for. Finish with an awesome, juggy topout.
content.location: Follow the trail to the lowers, and this is the SE face of the biggest boulder.

content.description: Brass Monkey is a fun, engaging, natural classic! Stand start with your right hand in a 2 finger pocket and your left hand on a jug undercling. Work your way up the angling prow using the vertical rail to a dynamic move to jugs on the ledge before the lip. Hit the lip, and work slightly right for a spicy topout.
content.location: This is located in the lower boulders. Take the social trail down just south of the parking at mile marker 7. You will approach the backside of the boulder (the downclimb). The climb is found on the opposite (west) side on the far left looking at the face.
